channel.title: Nature - Quantum
channel.description: Recent articles from Nature, Nature Physics, and Nature Photonics on Quantum Simulation.

item.title: Quantum error correction of qudits beyond break-even
item.author: Benjamin L. Brock, Shraddha Singh, Michel H. Devoret
item.content:encoded:
Quantum error correction of a logical qutrit and ququart were experimentally realized beyond the break-even point with the Gottesman–Kitaev–Preskill bosonic code.

Benjamin L. Brock, Shraddha Singh, Michel H. Devoret

item.title: Tunable vacuum-field control of fractional and integer quantum Hall phases
item.author: Josefine Enkner, Lorenzo Graziotto, Jérôme Faist
item.content:encoded:
Using a system to adjust the strength of cavity vacuum fields penetrating a Hall bar, a study describes the effect of the vacuum field of a cavity on electronic correlations in quantum Hall systems.

Josefine Enkner, Lorenzo Graziotto, Jérôme Faist

item.title: Bulk–spatiotemporal vortex correspondence in gyromagnetic zero-index media
item.author: Ruo-Yang Zhang, Xiaohan Cui, C. T. Chan
item.content:encoded:
Realization of a gyromagnetic double-zero-index metamaterial results in unconventional optical and topological properties, suitable to be used for the generation of light pulses shaped as a vortex both in time and space.

Ruo-Yang Zhang, Xiaohan Cui, C. T. Chan

item.title: Why bad philosophy is stopping progress in physics
item.author: Carlo Rovelli
item.content:encoded:
Theoretical physicists are in thrall to a misguided mindset that allows viable ideas to be advanced only by overturning what already exists.

Carlo Rovelli

item.title: Superconductivity and spin canting in spin–orbit-coupled trilayer graphene
item.author: Caitlin L. Patterson, Owen I. Sheekey, Andrea F. Young
item.content:encoded:
Introducing spin–orbit coupling by substrate proximity effect leads to an enhancement of superconducting phases in rhombohedral trilayer graphene.

Caitlin L. Patterson, Owen I. Sheekey, Andrea F. Young

item.title: Twist-programmable superconductivity in spin–orbit-coupled bilayer graphene
item.author: Yiran Zhang, Gal Shavit, Stevan Nadj-Perge
item.content:encoded:
The superconductivity in Bernal bilayer graphene that emerges from the spin–orbit coupling induced by proximal tungsten diselenide can be tuned by modulating the twist angle between the two materials.

Yiran Zhang, Gal Shavit, Stevan Nadj-Perge

item.title: Trump proposes unprecedented budget cuts to US science
item.author: Jeff Tollefson, Dan Garisto, Alexandra Witze
item.content:encoded:
Huge reductions, if enacted, could have ‘catastrophic’ effects on US competitiveness and the scientific pipeline, critics say.

Jeff Tollefson, Dan Garisto, Alexandra Witze

item.title: Quantum communication across a 250-kilometre optical-fibre network
item.author: Unknown Author
item.content:encoded:
Quantum communication over long distances can be achieved by exploiting a property of light called coherence. The coherence-based exchange of a ‘quantum encryption key’ over an optical telecommunications network demonstrates the feasibility of implementing a large-scale quantum network in existing telecommunications infrastructure.

Unknown Author

item.title: Long-distance coherent quantum communications in deployed telecom networks
item.author: Mirko Pittaluga, Yuen San Lo, Andrew J. Shields
item.content:encoded:
A twin-field quantum key distribution protocol based on optical coherence is deployed over a 254-kilometre commercial telecom network, demonstrating that coherence-based quantum communication can be aligned with existing telecommunication infrastructure.

Mirko Pittaluga, Yuen San Lo, Andrew J. Shields

item.title: Don’t believe the hype — quantum tech can’t yet solve real-world problems
item.author: Joan Arrow
item.content:encoded:
Investors and the public should know what quantum devices can and, more importantly, can’t do.

Joan Arrow

item.title: Antiferromagnetic quantum anomalous Hall effect under spin flips and flops
item.author: Zichen Lian, Yongchao Wang, Yayu Wang
item.content:encoded:
A new device based on 7-septuple-layer MnBi2Te4 covered with an AlOx capping layer enables the investigation of antiferromagnetic quantum anomalous Hall effect over wide parameter spaces.

Zichen Lian, Yongchao Wang, Yayu Wang

item.title: Observation of the axion quasiparticle in 2D MnBi2Te4
item.author: Jian-Xiang Qiu, Barun Ghosh, Su-Yang Xu
item.content:encoded:
The dynamical axion quasiparticle, which is directly analogous to the hypothetical fundamental axion particle, is observed in two-dimensional MnBi2Te4, and has implications for quantum chromodynamics, cosmology and string theory.

Jian-Xiang Qiu, Barun Ghosh, Su-Yang Xu

item.title: How the United States became a science superpower — and how quickly it could crumble
item.author: Steve Blank
item.content:encoded:
US global dominance in science was no accident, but a product of a far-seeing partnership between public and private sectors to boost innovation and economic growth.

Steve Blank

item.title: Daily briefing: Mysterious Taiwan fossil is Denisovan
item.author: Flora Graham
item.content:encoded:
A fossilized jawbone discovered more than 20 years ago belonged to a Denisovan. Plus, the states hit hardest by NIH cuts in charts and an acoustics lab inside an abandoned nuclear plant.

Flora Graham

item.title: ‘Mind blowing’: quantum computer untangles the mathematics of knots
item.author: Davide Castelvecchi
item.content:encoded:
Algorithms for studying knots and other topological objects could have a quantum advantage.

Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Near-field photon entanglement in total angular momentum
item.author: Amit Kam, Shai Tsesses, Guy Bartal
item.content:encoded:
Non-classical correlations between two photons in the near-field regime give rise to entanglement in their total angular momentum, leading to a completely different structure of quantum correlations of photon pairs.

Amit Kam, Shai Tsesses, Guy Bartal

item.title: Certified randomness using a trapped-ion quantum processor
item.author: Minzhao Liu, Ruslan Shaydulin, Marco Pistoia
item.content:encoded:
Certifiably random bits can be generated using the 56-qubit Quantinuum H2-1 trapped-ion quantum computer accessed over the Internet.

Minzhao Liu, Ruslan Shaydulin, Marco Pistoia

item.title: Daily briefing: Why RNA hasn’t yet had its ‘AlphaFold’ moment
item.author: Flora Graham
item.content:encoded:
Protein-structure-prediction tools have transformed biology, but RNA is a tougher nut to crack. Plus, the NIH is cancelling COVID-19 research funds and how ‘qudits’ can boost quantum computing.

Flora Graham

item.title: Mathematician who reshaped theory of symmetry wins Abel Prize
item.author: Davide Castelvecchi
item.content:encoded:
Masaki Kashiwara is the first Japanese person to be awarded the most prestigious prize in mathematics.

Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Macrophages harness hepatocyte glutamate to boost liver regeneration
item.author: María del Mar Rigual, Mariana Angulo-Aguado, Nabil Djouder
item.content:encoded:
Glutamate metabolically reprograms bone-marrow-derived macrophages, stabilizing HIF1α, which transcriptionally activates WNT3 to promote YAP1-dependent hepatocyte proliferation, boosting liver regeneration.

María del Mar Rigual, Mariana Angulo-Aguado, Nabil Djouder

item.title: Meet ‘qudits’: more complex cousins of qubits boost quantum computing
item.author: Davide Castelvecchi
item.content:encoded:
Working with multi-dimensional entities could make calculations more efficient and reduce errors.

Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Daily briefing: Babies make memories — so why don’t we recall them?
item.author: Flora Graham
item.content:encoded:
Babies as young as one year old can form memories, our adult brains just can’t access them. Plus, US-funded researchers outside the United States are being grilled about ideology and physicists suggest a ‘crazy’ new way we could generate electricity.

Flora Graham

item.title: Daily briefing: The mysterious force pushing galaxies apart might be getting weaker
item.author: Jacob Smith
item.content:encoded:
Mysterious ‘dark energy’ — thought to be a cosmological constant — might have weakened over billions of years. Plus, skin immune cells form their own ‘bandage’ around wounds and how astronomers are tackling the growing problem of satellite pollution.

Jacob Smith

item.title: Microsatellite-based real-time quantum key distribution
item.author: Yang Li, Wen-Qi Cai, Jian-Wei Pan
item.content:encoded:
A quantum microsatellite, with a payload weighing only 23 kilograms, in combination with portable ground stations that weigh merely 100 kilograms, is capable of performing space-to-ground real-time quantum key distribution.

Yang Li, Wen-Qi Cai, Jian-Wei Pan

item.title: A practical leap towards secure quantum communication over long distances
item.author: Unknown Author
item.content:encoded:
A network of quantum satellites that communicate with ground stations could offer a solution to enable a global quantum network. A quantum microsatellite that has been developed and launched can perform space-to-ground quantum communication using portable ground stations.

Unknown Author

item.title: Mini-satellite paves the way for quantum messaging anywhere on Earth
item.author: Elizabeth Gibney
item.content:encoded:
A Chinese team has transmitted quantum-encrypted images a record 12,900 kilometres.

Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: Tiny satellite sets new record for secure quantum communication
item.author: Shamini Bundell, Nick Petrić Howe
item.content:encoded:
Laser-based system allows quantum-encrypted information to be beamed across the globe, plus — an AI that can improve other AIs via written feedback, and an update on science in the US in the wake of Trump team’s cuts.

Shamini Bundell, Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: Down-converted photon pairs in a high-Q silicon nitride microresonator
item.author: Bohan Li, Zhiquan Yuan, Kerry Vahala
item.content:encoded:
Spontaneous parametric down-conversion was used to generate narrowband photon pairs with a high spectral brightness in a high-Q silicon nitride microresonator.

Bohan Li, Zhiquan Yuan, Kerry Vahala

item.title: A polyene macrolide targeting phospholipids in the fungal cell membrane
item.author: Qisen Deng, Yinchuan Li, Zongqiang Wang
item.content:encoded:
Mandimycin, a polyene macrolide, exhibits strong antifungal activity and possesses a mode of action that is distinct from other compounds of this class.

Qisen Deng, Yinchuan Li, Zongqiang Wang

item.title: Cooper-pair density modulation state in an iron-based superconductor
item.author: Lingyuan Kong, Michał Papaj, Stevan Nadj-Perge
item.content:encoded:
Pair density modulation, an unusual superconducting state whose superconducting gap is modulated by the wavelength corresponding to the lattice periodicity, is described and observed in exfoliated thin flakes of the iron-based superconductor FeTe0.55Se0.45.

Lingyuan Kong, Michał Papaj, Stevan Nadj-Perge

item.title: Hyperbolic phonon-polariton electroluminescence in 2D heterostructures
item.author: Qiushi Guo, Iliya Esin, Fengnian Xia
item.content:encoded:
All-electrical excitation of the hyperbolic phonon polaritons in hexagonal boron nitride by drifting charge carriers in nearby graphene results in electroluminescence at mid-infrared frequencies.

Qiushi Guo, Iliya Esin, Fengnian Xia

item.title: Microsoft quantum-computing claim still lacks evidence: physicists are dubious
item.author: Dan Garisto
item.content:encoded:
Some attendees at a packed presentation were curious about the prospect of the first ‘topological’ qubits, but left with questions unanswered.

Dan Garisto

item.title: A century of quantum physics
item.author: Unknown Author
item.content:encoded:
A Nature special.

Unknown Author

item.title: An operating system for executing applications on quantum network nodes
item.author: C. Delle Donne, M. Iuliano, S. Wehner
item.content:encoded:
A new quantum operating system architecture is described that is capable of executing applications on quantum networks in high-level software, which is a step towards bringing quantum network technology to society.

C. Delle Donne, M. Iuliano, S. Wehner

item.title: An operating system for networked quantum computers is a huge practical step forward
item.author: Claudio Cicconetti
item.content:encoded:
Quantum computers have gained the powerful abstractions that allow programmers of classical computers to design and integrate new apps and hardware, and connect devices into networks with ease.

Claudio Cicconetti

item.title: Fresh ‘quantum advantage’ claim made by computing firm D-Wave
item.author: Davide Castelvecchi
item.content:encoded:
The company says it has solved the first problem of scientific relevance with a quantum processor faster than would be done using classical computers.

Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Author Correction: Observation of Nagaoka polarons in a Fermi–Hubbard quantum simulator
item.author: Martin Lebrat, Muqing Xu, Markus Greiner
item.content:encoded:
No Description

Martin Lebrat, Muqing Xu, Markus Greiner

item.title: Daily briefing: Saturn has 128 new moons
item.author: Flora Graham
item.content:encoded:
Blue-lined octopuses immobilize their partners with venom to avoid being eaten after sex. Plus, astronomers have discovered 128 new moons orbiting Saturn.

Flora Graham

item.title: Unconventional magnons in collinear magnets dictated by spin space groups
item.author: Xiaobing Chen, Yuntian Liu, Qihang Liu
item.content:encoded:
Spin space group theory is applied to identify more than 200 collinear magnets with unconventional magnons; high-throughput calculations with spin–orbit coupling find that most of these unconventional magnets are dictated by the Heisenberg exchange interaction.

Xiaobing Chen, Yuntian Liu, Qihang Liu

item.title: Magnetically and optically active edges in phosphorene nanoribbons
item.author: Arjun Ashoka, Adam J. Clancy, Raj Pandya
item.content:encoded:
Phosphorene nanoribbons demonstrate extraordinary magnetic properties, ranging from large internal fields in films to macroscopic alignment in solution, which can be coupled to photoexcitations that localize to the magnetic edge of these ribbons.

Arjun Ashoka, Adam J. Clancy, Raj Pandya

item.title: Microsoft quantum computing ‘breakthrough’ faces fresh challenge
item.author: Dan Garisto
item.content:encoded:
Analysis pokes holes in protocol that underpins Microsoft’s claim to have created the first topological qubits.

Dan Garisto

item.title: Daily briefing: This key protein could be responsible for brain ageing
item.author: Flora Graham
item.content:encoded:
A key protein that could be responsible for brain ageing. Plus, researchers organize a day of action to #StandUpForScience.

Flora Graham

item.title: A manufacturable platform for photonic quantum computing
item.author: Koen Alexander, Avishai Benyamini, Xinran Zhou
item.content:encoded:
A manufacturable platform for quantum computing with photons is introduced and a set of monolithically integrated silicon-photonics-based modules is benchmarked, demonstrating dual-rail photonic qubits with performance close to thresholds required for operation.

Koen Alexander, Avishai Benyamini, Xinran Zhou

item.title: Hardware-efficient quantum error correction via concatenated bosonic qubits
item.author: Harald Putterman, Kyungjoo Noh, Oskar Painter
item.content:encoded:
Bosonic qubits can be engineered to feature intrinsic protection against certain kinds of errors, which makes quantum error correction across many bosonic qubits possible with less overhead.

Harald Putterman, Kyungjoo Noh, Oskar Painter

item.title: Multiplexed entanglement of multi-emitter quantum network nodes
item.author: A. Ruskuc, C.-J. Wu, A. Faraon
item.content:encoded:
Multiplexed entanglement distribution in a quantum network, with each node comprising multiple solid-state emitters in nanophotonic cavities, enables scalable quantum communication.

A. Ruskuc, C.-J. Wu, A. Faraon

item.title: Quantum technologies need big investments to deliver on their big promises
item.author: Jian-Wei Pan
item.content:encoded:
Sustained investments can deliver quantum devices that handle more information, more rapidly and more securely than can classical ones.

Jian-Wei Pan

item.title: Mass-spectrometry-based proteomics: from single cells to clinical applications
item.author: Tiannan Guo, Judith A. Steen, Matthias Mann
item.content:encoded:
This Review summarizes advances in mass-spectrometry-based proteomics and explores the potential applications of these technologies in the clinic.

Tiannan Guo, Judith A. Steen, Matthias Mann

item.title: Orbital hybridization in graphene-based artificial atoms
item.author: Yue Mao, Hui-Ying Ren, Qing-Feng Sun
item.content:encoded:
Orbital hybridization in artificial atoms is achieved by altering their shape, and the anisotropy of the confining potential gives rise to the hybridization between quasibound states with different orbital quantum numbers within the artificial atom.

Yue Mao, Hui-Ying Ren, Qing-Feng Sun

item.title: Will AI jeopardize science photography? There’s still time to create an ethical code of conduct
item.author: Felice Frankel
item.content:encoded:
Generative artificial-intelligence illustrations can be helpful, but fall short as scientific records.

Felice Frankel

item.title: Trump’s siege of science: how the first 30 days unfolded and what’s next
item.author: Jeff Tollefson, Max Kozlov, Dan Garisto
item.content:encoded:
The breakneck pace and devastating impact of the administration’s policy changes has shocked researchers.

Jeff Tollefson, Max Kozlov, Dan Garisto
